commentBody:
As noted last night, I did the Tuesday puzzle 35.1% faster than my Tuesday average.  I did Monday's puzzle 26.9% faster than my Monday average.

I did this one 42.1% faster than my Wednesday average, although in actual minutes and seconds, it took me almost a minute longer.

Xwstats.com's rating for this one is currently Easy, but that might change eventually.

It's definitely easy week at the NYT.  Maybe not coincidentally, they're pushing us to convert to multi-user subscriptions recently.  Maybe it's easy week for the newbies.  I hope there's a little more bite in the next few puzzles.
This is a classic!  Very nice construction and clueing.  I know Seinfeld fairly well but still got the Seinfeld catchphrase last.
I had to laugh at the odd formality of 29D (GIVE ME FIVE).  I can't imagine anyone ever saying that instead of "Gimme five."
Trying to parse the clue in such a way that [Sources of lines for a reading, maybe] indicates PALM instead of PALMS. Any explanations from more seasoned solvers? What did I miss? Thanks.

And that's 200 Days.

My Seinfeld Facebook group will be very happy about today's theme
Fun!
Is SLAG the new Oreo?

Another PB, two days in a row. This is the easiest week I can remember.

ALCOA, SLAG, ORE - somebody on a smelting kick today?

I find it unbelievable that MAV shows up in almost the exact same spot with almost the exact same clue two days on a row. 

Other than that, this was a personal best time for Wednesdays for me.

Loved this puzzle and its rites of passage! Of course, the kicker, Hello new man forces the puzzle to have only male rituals, and that's a potential drawback, or is it? I wouldn't have pointed this out if all the themers were female-oriented. We all have baggage, and some check it at the gate and others bring it with us. 

Well, on to Alcoa, the Aluminum Company of America. Aluminum is the third most abundant element in earth's crust and the most common metal, but it's rarely found in its pure form, it must be refined from its ORE -- mainly found in bauxite, and the greatest abundance of bauxite in the western hemisphere is in Brazil: early on Alcoa established bauxite mines in Suriname and Brazil. Bauxite was then refined, producing aluminum hydroxide, which was then smelted in an electrolytic process to produce aluminum. And its byproducts do indeed include quite a bit of SLAG. If you'd like more information on aluminum and its history, I'm here all week.

For me, I can't tell which I hate more, using -- and then discarding -- aluminum foil (the idea of throwing out metal, of wasting metal to cover bowls of leftovers, horrible!) or using -- and then discarding -- saran wrap. It's all such a waste. I'll go eat my oaten biscuit now and XYZ.
Free Palestine

Good puzzle.  Slightly easier than average for a Wednesday but good cluing, nice theme with HELLO NEWMAN.

Figures the last square I got was not knowing the full correct spelling of BAR MITZVAH.  I knew what it was right away but I spelled it BAR MITSFAH first.  Got the V early for ON THE VERGE.  But the last square I got was the Z because GISMO and GIZMO are both valid spellings.

And I wasn't sure I had another square wrong because I wasn't sure about ALCOA/CATO square.  SE was the hardest area of the puzzle for me by far.

I thought this was just going to be four rites of passage‚Äîwhich would have been ok since finding four symmetrical ones is a feat, and it was a fairly chewy Wednesday for me. But the fun revealer made it a bit more special and brought back fond memories, even if it may be a bit dated for some.
I can thank my son for teaching me about Rumspringa‚Äîeven if I couldn‚Äôt pull it out right away‚Äîhe once wrote a script about it for a film class.
I liked the clueing for this puzzle‚Äîeven if the grid was pretty basic I found it ambiguous enough that I had  to think about it.

Reading that one of this week‚Äôs constructors has been doing Times puzzles for 65 years, and contributing for the first time, is incredible! Congrats!

Super fun puzzle. Love when my fascination with Rumspringa and love of Usher intersect!

Face-palmed when it hit me that "Oatey" was my mistake. I kept trying to imagine Kramer saying "hello yew man" and wondering if I had missed a key episode. It still sounds like something he would say.

Ok, to dispense with the requisite self-flattery: did my crossword in 2.5 microseconds, so easy, omg why won‚Äôt the NYT challenge us. 

On to other things. By now I (as, I‚Äôm sure, most regulars) have come to mechanically start typing EROICA when I spot the words ‚ÄúBeethoven‚Äù and ‚Äúsymphony‚Äù in the same clue. And though this isn‚Äôt the first time that the piece‚Äôs original dedication to Napoleon has come up, I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about the legend of Beethoven angrily scratching the name ‚ÄúBonaparte‚Äù out of the symphony‚Äôs manuscript as soon as he heard the French statesman had crowned himself emperor. 

The Napoleon dedication was part of a larger Promethean theme (both musically and ideologically) B had been developing. He saw Napoleon as the hero who was willing to run afoul of the aristocratic Olympus to give humanity the gift of the republic. (In fact, he was kind of obsessed with these heroic notions throughout his middle period.)

The point is: in the thick of his thirst for a hero to lionize, Beethoven realized his republican idol was just another greedy mortal and flew into a rage. He grieved. 

Why does this idea seem so farcical now, when time and again it is made clear that Trump is not some hero bent on freeing the masses from the oppressive ancien r√©gime, and every time his supporters‚Äô reaction is to pretend they never wanted the republic to begin with? Is there anything that would make them scratch out the name ‚ÄúTrump‚Äù from their proverbial symphonic score?
Fun theme! Puzzle was very easy for me until the SE corner which took a long time and one lookup (57A) to even have a chance.
Crosswords are easier when you know how to spell Dehli
Shouldn‚Äôt 24D PALM be plural due to the clue ‚Äúsources‚Äù?

The plot twist waiting in the revealer completely shifted the tone of this puzzle. A delight!

The beauty of this particular catch phrase being "in the language" for three decades is that it isn't something we've integrated while the origin fades from the context. It's maintained it's originality so succinctly that we all heard Jerry's voice utter this salutation through audibly gritted teeth the moment it clicked. 

(Although admittedly when I initially saw "Seinfeld catch phrase" in the clue my first instinct was to wonder how I was going to fit "king of my domain" into the spaces provided. That's another puzzle idea for another day, I suppose!)

Re: 49D:  I‚Äôve mentioned this before, but I‚Äôll say it again:  the material used to make roads, sidewalks, etc is ‚Äúconcrete‚Äù of which cement is an ingredient.  So we do not TROWEL cement, but the concrete that it‚Äôs an essential part of.  

Fun puzzle and I really enjoyed the revealer!

And in a nod to Sam, I am the father of 2 Jewish daughters so my instinctive answer for 30A was BatMITZVAH ü§£

Great theme. I got the revealer after solving VISION QUEST and BA_MITZVAH. I had initially started with BA_ knowing it could go either way until I read the clue for the revealer. Aha! Definitely BAR. Here is a compilation of Jerry and Newman greeting each other‚Ä¶ üòÜ https://youtu.be/u-O9xFnhlfM?si=6H2LJkC676oMXc6x Thank you for the fun romp, Hanh and Ted (and congratulations on the debut, Ted)!

There simply was too much trivia in this puzzle for it to be enjoyable to me (yes, Francis, I used the t word, boo hoo). The editing error in the clue for PALM didn't help, either (a single palm can't be the *sources* of lines for a reading, can it...)

I've never seen Seinfeld so the revealer did nothing for me. I was only vaguely aware of the name of the Amish rite of passage (it came up on "Bones", but I didn't remember the exact name). I knew VISION QUEST though - I learned it from "Star Trek: Voyager", of all places ü§£. The Jewish rite I know from films and TV, too.

I was quite annoyed by the whole thing so I checked the puzzle when I predictably got the "So close" pop-up. Isn't there something condescending and taunting about it? I was not close - I was utterly lost and dejected. That pop-up has the insulting feel of a participation trophy - hey, you failed, but at least you tried (badly)!
As others have noted, the clue and the answer for 24D don't match (SOURCES is plural and PALM is singular). That's such a  careless error. Do the NYT editors ever admit to making a mistake?
I got stuck in the SE corner for a while because I had HEINZ instead of ALCOA‚Ä¶ Anyone else?
If only ‚ÄúI wish it were so‚Äù had been ifonly. But ALASNO.
Love that use of Craters, about time Seinfeld clues fall in completely too but overall some good ones in there. Completely missed the Palm problem with it solving from crossings.
I wonder if "means of transport" started off as a cause of head scratching for crossword solvers.

That was pretty sticky for me. Never saw Seinfeld, RUM what now? Industrial who? And so on and so forth. I don‚Äôt mind, always good to have something new to learn. Off to ask Google what the heck RUMSPRINGA is now. Toodles.

Nice to see our off-stage PALS (SIC)* get recognition for feeding us lines when we‚Äôre practicing.

*sorry for shouting in all caps, just trying to be loud and clear.

Speaking of ON THE VERGE, world-class crossword constructor and speed-solver Paolo Pasco has taken a commanding lead in Jeopardy's Tournament of Champions.

He is not only likable, funny, knowledgeable, and adept at playing the game, but in wordplay categories, his brain seems amazingly super-human.

He's being doing this pastime of ours proud.  Go Paolo!

I've heard it said that young people don't get "judgment" until they're in their twenties. Well, I can testify, oh never mind.,, How about SWEETSIXTEEN QUINCINERA or WALKABOUT? Have you seen the film about the Australian coming-of-age ritual? https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0067959/ Unfortunately, the real rite of passage in our society is FIRSTCAR which also serves as a first (mobile) home!! But then there's also, again unfortunately, FIRSTUNPAIDINTERNSHIP.....

Quite a few things I didn't know, and no matter; I tried my best with the crossers. I've never seen Seinfeld either. The actors/musicians, the sport, the snack, the company ... and I say ECG not EKG - I wonder why? 

The isle of Islay  (pronounced EYE-LA) is beautiful and worth a visit, apart from the peaty whisky!

Once I revealed some, I realised that the theme is really interesting and clever.
love a crossword solve that makes me smile

Of course I knew BAR MITZVAH and had heard of RUMSPRINGA, but VISION QUEST was a new one for me, which I got from the crosses. But I didn't get the totality of the theme until the revealer, and then I broke out in a great big grin. Very clever, even though I knew that most non-native English speakers wouldn't be happy with this puzzle (Here's looking at you, Andrjez!)

Uggggggh "SLAG" not "SLAB"

It would have been nice if the cross wasn't a Native American tribe nobody has heard of.

Having skipped over the VISION QUEST on my first pass through, my initial thought for 30A was CIRCUMCISN, which didn‚Äôt even look misspelled to me at first! And I am usually a pretty good speller. After realizing that RUMSPRINGA was another theme answer, I figured I‚Äôd picked the wrong rite. Then I had to wonder how man-hands, shrinkage, sponge-worthy, or ‚Äúno soup for you‚Äù could possibly fit into the space allotted.
RUMSPRINGA.  My brain tapped me on the shoulder and started singing ‚ÄúGoldfinger‚Äù, substituting this word.

All I can think of is, "Can one go "up top!" with a single PALM?"

But seriously folks, a very clever and funny theme so well done. 

I've tried those PEATY Scotches, taste like a 3 day old fireplace.

Congrats to Mr. Mayer on a fun debut and a successful collaboration with the creative Hanh Huynh.

Who can resist a puzzle that includes RUMSPRINGA?

My kind of puzzle, wordplay-abounding in theme and clue.

I tried hard to guess the revealer, leaving it blank and not reading its clue, to no avail, and when I finally uncovered HELLO NEWMAN, well, that was a knock-me-over banger.  Sure, the terrific wordplay, but also its iconic sardonic delivery.  There is only one way to say it, and it‚Äôs funny.

That moment turned this puzzle from a simple fill-in to a worth-the-price-of-admission.

That‚Äôs on top of the clue wordplay scattered about.  Such as [Ball one or ball two] for EYE ‚Äì an answer that has appeared more than 500 times in the major crossword outlets, but never clued like this.  

Kudos to the constructors for coming up with this theme set that fit symmetry and setting it in a cleanly filled grid.  

Loved it.  For me, this was Hanh and Ted‚Äôs great adventure.  Thank you both, and congratulations on your debut, Ted!

Here are the stats for today's puzzle from xwstats.com, though with those numbers, I can't really see why they're calling this puzzle "Average":

üåé  Global Stats
Difficulty
Average
Median Solve Time
4:45
Median Solver
18% faster
‚ö°85% of users solved faster than their Monday average.
45% solved much faster (>20%) than their Monday average.
üê¢15% of users solved slower than their Monday average.
5% solved much slower (>20%) than their Monday average.

One the slow side for me with a couple of completely unfamiliar terms. No big deal- managed to work it out from the crosses. Puzzle find today was inspired by 37a (RAVEN). A Sunday from December 3, 1972 by Elmer Toro with the title: "Wild Life." Some theme clue and answer examples: "Bye-bye blackbird? QUOTHTHERAVENNEVERMORE "Start of a certain recipe" EYEOFNEWANDTOEOFFROG "Blake's vision." TIGERTIGERBURNINGBRIGHT And a couple of other theme answers: ANDLETSLIPTHEDOGSOFWAR WHEREEAGLESDARENOTPERCH ANDWHETHERPIGSHAVEWINGS Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/3/1972&g=94&d=A ....

My girlfriend and I were thrilled to know EROICA from having seen it performed at the symphony a few months ago, but I guess doing the crossword for several decades and being clued in to its familiar rhythms is another way to go about it! Loved this puzzle and it came together pretty painlessly. HELLO NEW MAN made me cackle.

Little SUSIE and Beethoven's Third in the same puzzle? Happiness is. 
Like Andrzej, I knew of RUMSPRINGA from the Bones episode.

Kind of shocked we're giving Seinfeld any kind of cultural relevancy in the year 2026, but here we are. 

This was fine. Not having watched the show, the revealer didn't grab me, and I was able to solve the themed clues on their own merit. Really not sure why we bothered with using Seinfeld as connective tissue at all. 

I found the top half way more doable than the bottom. Not sure if the two constructors split this puzzle in its creation or what, but I felt that discordant shift at about the halfway point. Not the most elegant construction.

The cluing was fun though. A lot of wordplay, a good range of subject matter. Maybe a few too many sports references for my personal taste, but hopefully it appeases those who claim sports clues never make it into these puzzles. The clue for EYE can go, though. Never should have been accepted. 

Happy Wednesday.
Eroica, Arepa, Alcoa, and Anya was too much for me. I had to look up Eroica and then guessed the others. Otherwise, another fun puzzle. Thank you, creator. Cheers.

Nice misdirects in the clues....though of course I did not know the movie, the actress, or the rapper.  

I don't mind archaic language, but if you ever use the term OATEN, please raise your hand to participate in my survey.....
(I thought not.  It's not one of those useful terms.)

We lived near several Amish communities in NE Ohio.  A few folks made a living giving rides to Amish teens who had jobs in the local  area.  After a surgery, I had a girl coming to clean for a while.  As soon as she got on the van, she produced lipstick, eye shadow, rouge--and had transformed herself by the time she arrived at our house.  (Education ended after 8th grade.  Some girls became teachers--"We just think about our schooling and talk to our mothers, and go ahead.")

I'm old enough to remember "Mean" Joe Greene and the Purple People Eaters, so 37A was obviously the Vikings!  When that didn't fit I had rack my brain for "Ravens".  They were the "Colts" in Joe Greene's time

Palm or palms? Singular or plural? All uses are correct because all palms are descended from the great and all-powerful Palm. Hence the phrase "Palm springs eternal".

And now for something completely different, i.e. not (intentionally)absurd:

Sam writes that the revealer "clue refers to the disdainful greeting that Jerry Seinfeld uses when his archnemesis and neighbor shows up at the door."

I'm not saying "archnemesis and neighbor" is wrong but it sounds backwards to me. I feel like I've only ever seen or read "xxx and archnemesis".

Does anybody agree? Can anyone explain it?

I really love the photograph that accompanies today's Wordplay column. It reminds me of the famous Classical sculpture of the Discus Thrower (the Diskobolus by Myron). Both works show an athlete, apparently deeply focused on their athletic endeavors, but really demonstrating the beauty of form and line. Google Lens identified the thrower as American javelin thrower Creth Hines, who competed for the USA in the 1928 Olympics, but the subject of this photograph doesn't much look like Hines. A deeper dive shows that the photograph is by the German-Israeli photographer, Liselotte Grschebina, but I couldn't identify the athlete. It was enlightening and pleasurable to explore her work in greater depth. https://www.europeana.eu/en/collections/person/130464-liselotte-grschebina

Great Wednesday puzzle. A small and admittedly nit-picky comment from someone who works in the cement and concrete industry. Cement is the precursor product to concrete, and is a fine, soft powder. One would not use a trowel to ‚Äúspread‚Äù cement, as one would not be spreading cement at all. The correct clue for 49 down would replace ‚Äúcement‚Äù with ‚Äúconcrete‚Äù, the final product that is actually used for masonry, construction and other end-use applications. Cheers!

One of the more educational puzzles I've ever done -- or at least it would be if I made the effort to immerse myself in the ins and outs of VISION QUEST and RUMSPRINGA, two coming of age rituals I never heard of.  Of course I've heard of a BAR MITZVAH -- as has just about everyone I imagine.  But being me, I probably won't immerse myself in the ins and outs of VISION QUEST and RUMSPRINGA -- I'll just take the constructors' word for it.

Did many of you not want to write in the very peculiar RUMSPRINGA?  If you don't already know ir, it sort of looks like a typo.

As soon as I had HELLO, I knew the next word was NEWMAN.  I'm a real Seinfeld fan.  And I enjoyed the wordplay and the double meaning.  I think the theme is pretty neat.

A big nit at 24D:  You can't clue a singular answer with a plural clue.  I thought of PALM immediately, but since it wasn't a plural, I didn't write it in.  When I finally had to, I was annoyed.

And I think the clue "Ball one or ball two" for EYE is beyond weird.

But basically I liked this cute and educational puzzle.
Yesterday was a Tuesday PR and today was a Wednesday PR. Wish this week were a little harder, hope tomorrow is tricky!

In the spirit of Dr. Seuss and his characters Thing 1 and Thing 2 from "The Cat in the Hat", I am renaming my eyes Ball 1 and Ball 2.

The trick will be remembering which is which.

Quick side-of-the-Atlantic check: 24D should have been clued in the singular, right? One that got past the editors? Or is there an Americanism I don‚Äôt know about? (I don‚Äôt mean that facetiously; it‚Äôs often the explanation and this is how I find out!)
Congrats to the constructors for finding the one KEANU Reeves movie I'd never heard of. And LISA is an odd name for any rapper, let alone a Korean one. It's just so...ordinary, and spelled correctly.

The comments here are wild to me. People noting "quite a few things I didn't know," as though that is something to be noted. First, we are sadly losing knowledge of anything not pop culture. We should know way more, and we should feel bad that we don't. 

Second, you're really, really not supposed to be able to easily fill in every clue with your "knowledge." It's supposed to require advanced knowledge, thinking, and over all, PUZZLING.

No clue about the Seinfeld catchphrase, so today I had to solve an inverse problem, i.e., using the theme to ascertain the revealer. This made the puzzle a bit more interesting than a typical Wednesday for me.

Knew RUMSPRINGA, and I seemed to be on the right wavelength today. Finished in about ten minutes without assistance, yet today's puzzle didn't feel unusually easy to me (like yesterday's did).

LIked this one, all in all, despite a pretty minimal theme.
Great puzzle. I usually only comment to complain but this time I thought I would say something positive
Wouldn't PALM S be "Sources of lines...", and PALM "Source of lines...?
Quick hint - Hem or Cuff are verbs, not nouns. If you have pants hemmed, they are being what? Now use the present tense. You got this!
Eyeball 1 & eyeball 2 ??

I see some folks complaining that this puzzle was too easy. Personally I thought it was a fine Wednesday. Maybe a bit breezy, but sometimes they‚Äôre harder and sometimes they‚Äôre easier. 

Especially on a Wednesday. Humpday. The crossword crossover day.
Thank you. That reveal was so corny and I really needed a corny laugh today. Also a new fastest Wednesday time.

Major issue here with 33D and I expect a full correction tomorrow. 

"Any of Scar's underlings in The Lion King" solves to HYENA. 

While Zazu initially served Mufasa and remained loyal to him, he was taken prisoner by Scar and made to do Scar's bidding. I would therefore argue that Zazu was Scar's underling.

Zazu was an African red-billed hornbill. I'm shocked and appalled by this error, frankly.
Years ago, our adopted British nephew, introduced us to Digestive Biscuits. Thanks Allie. YUM.

Yada Yada Yada

Fun and clever!
Thanks!

Today‚Äôs poem from today‚Äôs puzz

a/ in the great walls
of the great passage
loud and loud
the heartbeat of the great giant
the talk of dogs
i wake a wish of what might be
of how the coyote
d/ with unforced lips
collapses in heat
collapses in oceans
a/ blabs hello

I enjoy imagining a VISION QUEST, BAR MITZVAH, or RUMSPRINGA including the only thing I know about Seinfeld:

Babka. (Chocolate.)

Too bad, "These pretzels are making me thirsty" didn't fit! Someone should really do a theme around that. Har! Or, "The sea was angry that day, my friends." 

A fun and fast puzzle, which was good because I was running all kinds of late for work today, thanks to a migraine, which is also why I haven't read more than a few of the earliest and latest comments. Hope everyone, or most people, enjoyed this as much as I did‚Äîonce I was able to get the migraine to pass, anyhow. Thankfully, they don't last days for me, like I know they do for some. 

Anyhow, I did get the revealer right away and figured out the theme. I knew the three theme answers, but unfortunately had some misspellings in two of them. Words I've heard more than I've actually seen spelled out, I guess. Easy to untangle though and I finished up significantly faster than my average. (Well, that's true of every day this week.)

I don't know of Lisa and Blackpink but I wonder if she is an EVIL DIVA. 

Giddy up!!
Tough and chewy Wednesday‚Ä¶

I came on here to complain about what an easy Thursday this was (and no tricks!). I read through some of the comments, and mentally corrected the first person who said this was a great Wednesday puzzle. 

By the third mention of Wednesday I had to gingerly get off my high horse and accept my error.

Happy almost Thursday!
Concrete is spread with a trowel. Not CEMENT.
Delightful. Loved the theme!

Since we're on rites of passage, let me recommend a great sci-fi novel with that title by Alexei Panshin. It's about a small community living permanently in space on a habitat created from an asteroid, who have to keep their population limited and competent, and do it by dropping teens for a month on a planet to see if they survive. There is skill training offered and the teens can take gear and even team up once dropped. Won't say more....

Glad to know that I'm not the only one to notice that the clue for PALM had a mistake.

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

Man, that was tough for a Wednesday, but not for being extra clever.

For me, there were too many names, terms, definitions, what have you.

I got the gold star unaided in okay time (26 m), but it wasn't much fun.
Okay sharing my excitement that not only did I get the theme; I also only had to look up a handful of super American references. Woohoo getting better.

I found this generally light going until the bottom right. Diverse trivia:
Classical music
South/Central American cuisine
30 year old pop culture
Modern technology
(Minor character from) Classical studies. (Don't come at me)
Currently relevant movie star.
Construction equipment.

I unravelled it, but anyone could have been lucky or absolutely ruined down in that area.
I mean, I guess it's an Usher hit, but I would have expected a New York based publication to have been more likely to promote Candelita in 11 Across.
delicious!
Clicked for me. Under five. First time that happens on a Wednesday.
Got my Best Wednesday. Cute theme.

Love Seinfeld. Love to hate Newman. But oaten is not a thing (anybody look forward to their wheaten bread in the morning? Not even a marble(en) rye?)
Too many major fails. Two thumbs (way) down.

Felt like there was a lot of obscure words and trivia in here, wasn't really a fan.

Alcoa, cato, briar (pipe?) lout, eroica, slag, plus the revealer which I just had no idea about ... Made for a different top-center and bottom-right
My girlfriend asserts that Jennie is the lead rapper in Blackpink, Lisa is the lead dancer
Sexist and slightly racist....just like "Seinfeld" itself. Gross.

@Steve L

Monday and Tuesday were near records for me. Today was below average. I struggled a fair bit on my first across pass

@Steve L
Agreed. Finished Mon Tues Wed in under 18 min combined.

@Steve L

Had I known all the trivia, I would have finished this in Tuesday time. But I didn't,  and I finished quickly but only after checking the puzzle...

Andrzej,
They're clearly not looking to push puzzle subscriptions in Poland.

@Steve L

The push to multi-user subscriptions is so annoying.
I don't have anyone to share the subscription with, my crossword family is here.

And it's a great family, from young whipper-snappers to old geezers, curmudgeons and bubbly pollyannas, wise aunties and fun uncles. I appreciate the few black sheep, even.   
:)

@Barry Ancona

Not even for defense?

@Andrzej

In general, I find that when I know the answers I solve the puzzle more quickly.

@RichardZ

Right? It was one of the many confusing (rather than smartly misleading) bits of this puzzle.

@Pezhead

I think you are right in your instincts. "Source of lines for a reading" would make much more sense.

@Pezhead
I was also confused by this.
Wondered the same thing. If someone has a reasonable explanation I will do one face palm, or maybe two face palms.

userLocation: no longer writing like E. E. Cummings
commentBody:
@john ezra

It just be wrong, is the explanation.
I'm thinking it is an error.  It happens (but not as often as people think).
Wait a minute! You mean PALM isn't both the singular and the plural, like "Deer?"

@Pezhead thank you. I was going to ask the same question.  I couldn‚Äôt figure out how PALS was a source for lines except maybe you get fun stories from friends. And then SIC didn‚Äôt make much sense unless you yell out that something was wrong in the text. Doh!

@Larry R
I sat on PALS and SIC for a while too! But after three times through all the other answers I knew that was the problem spot. Then it hit me - MIC! - and when that got me the congratulations message I headed right over here to commiserate on the number mismatch between "Sources" and PALM.

@DocP

Well, it's going to one ore the other.

@DocP
And we had MAV twice this week!
@DocP we can slag people off here in Australia, so there‚Äôs at least one more clue option yet.

@Dave K.
Yeah, sensed it coming.  I smelt it from a mile away.

@Dave K.
Are you saying you smelt a rat?

@JAG

Actually this is the third time this week I think!

@JAG
I'm not sure whether there are any alternative ways of cluing it, other than various ways of referrimg to Dallas.

@SBK
There is NASA‚Äôs Mars Ascent Vehicle, I suppose, but there‚Äôs not much way to clue it without giving away the answer. Besides which, it doesn‚Äôt actually exist, just a concept.
@SBK Isn't that what Goose called Tom Cruise's character in Top Gun?

userLocation: ICE in Italia? Basta, ruffiani! Fuori!
commentBody:
@Ken
If true,  excellent catch! I would still call it a late-week clue but very useful.

Now that I've read a bit about Rumspringa, which I thought was purely for the lads, no apparently it's for Amish youth in general.

I need to get out more!

@john ezra way back when I was a broke student, there was no way I was about to waste part of my grocery $ on foil or plastic wrap. I just stuck a plate on top of the bowl. Not air tight but close enough. Now there are all those silicon lid snap-on containers but now and then I still grab a plate.
@john ezra It's really sexist to limit this to just "new men".

@Francis Americans have a permanent (or, at least until your fuehrer tears it down) reminder of how precious aluminum was -- the cap on the Washington Monument. It was planned and placed as a lightning rod in 1884 before the discovery of the new refinement process, when aluminum was still among the most expensive metals on earth. In 1886, the price of aluminum dropped because of the increased supply, falling below copper. For geeks only: more info here -- https://engineerine.com/aluminum-discovery-impact/

@john ezra

When I lived in Knoxville, I often drove through the little town of ALCOA, TN, on my way to the Smokies.  A nice reminder of a time not too long ago when a company could own a town.

@Moira
The revealer clue wouldn't make sense if the answer was HELLO NEW PERSON.
@john ezra who throws out foil any more? Wash and reuse till it‚Äôs full of holes and then put it in the recycling bin.

@Leontion
I still use a plate to cover food. And I use a cloth to wipe down, not paper towels.

@john ezra
Thanks for all the information about aluminum process. I'm from Massena NY, where Alcoa built an aluminum smelter in 1902. My dad worked for "the plant" from age 19 to retirement, eventually heading the Industrial engineering department. The whole town worked for or benefited from "the plant" in one way or another. The only thing I can add about the smelting process is that it used the Hall process, required immense amounts of electricity, and was highly polluting (though we didn't know the last thing at the time.)

@john ezra

I very vaguely remember my Granny using shower-cap like things to cover bowls of leftovers--a circle of plastic with elastic around the edge--they were not shower caps, but intended for kitchen use.  They'd work on several different sizes of bowls.  She'd washed and reused them for years.  

I thought that was a fairly good idea--less waste.   

Just a few years ago you could easily buy storage bowls with glass lids.  Now they have plastic lids so you have to buy new plastic lids all the time because they break.  More profit for the corporation!  

I use plates of different sizes flipped backside up as lids on bowls.  They seal quite nicely.

@McT, 

Interesting in reading the comments that the plate trick (which I also employ) is a go-to solution. I don't remember those quasi shower-cap things.

@SP

I would definitely comment on Ukraine if any Russian were mentioned.

@Andrzej

Have you though? Just out of the blue like that when the puzzle didn‚Äôt even bring it up?
I‚Äôm also wondering if this is just because BARMITZVAH was mentioned which is even worse.
This is not the place for this. I guarantee you if the puzzle referenced Zoram Mamdani and/or Ramadan in some random context, and I posted ‚ÄúDown with Hamas‚Äù because I politically believe he has supported them or at least not condemned them harshly enough, I would be flagged and excoriated here before you could say boo ‚Äîand I‚Äôm sure I will lose a lot of friends by even bringing it up tangentially. I‚Äôm doing it to make my point, I would not do it on this forum normally. No body else bothered by this?
@SP I‚Äôm very bothered by this as well and flagging it. This forum is not the place for this!

@Chris
Conventional spelling in English is BAR MITZVAH but, since it's just a transliteration of an Aramaic + Hebrew term, any set of letters that produced the same set of sounds when pronounced are equally valid. S could replace Z; just not in this puzzle.
@Leontion - Same here.  As I think tastes "oatey" is something someone would actually say, describing a biscuit.  Not "oaten".

@Lisa B, There are multiple lines, but a singular palm is only one source. This really tripped me up in the box

@Nikhil B

Same here.

@Lisa B No, one palm is one source. Lines are found within the source. 

Example:
Answer: book
Wrong clue: things you read
Right clue: thing you read
Doesn't matter that within the book you read pages or words, book is singular

@Abby Yep, on my first pass I thought "hmm, PALs can't be right", but I then filled in MIC and forgot about the plural. This is why you should never concentrate too much when doing crosswords. Like using soft hands to catch a ball.

@Grumpy

üòÇ  I guess it makes perfect sense that someone with your username  would have appreciated the Soup NŒ±zi.

@Francis

I'll one-up Grumpy - I've never seen a single scene from Seinfeld ü•≥

@Andrzej

I thought the show was genius.  It touched on so many social situations that are common but not much talked about.

One of my favorites was when Jerry got involved with a very nice girl, but somehow missed getting her name, and was now too embarrassed to ask it, as they've become so close.

All he could get out of her was that she was teased as a kid a lot because her name rhymed with a female body part, which opened up a whole line of comedy of words that rhymed with words they couldn't actually say on network TV.

I actually fell into that trap once.  Way early, when I was a young teen burning a trail through the Nazarene Church in southeastern Colorado, I met a girl in a nearby town, and we hung around with one another that Sunday.  (We were probably 14 or 15.)  I somehow didn't hear her name, and, like Jerry, was too embarrassed to ask.

Ultimately, it all came out next time I was there when I needed to introduce her.  She was justifiably furious, and I felt terrible, but also totally trapped by circumstances.

commentBody:
@Francis
One of the few advantages of getting old is indifference to amour-propre. I am past being embarrassed and will fearlessly say, 'I'm so sorry, I've forgotten your name.' (Of course, I have several strategies to get people to cough up their names, which I try first.) People are quite forgiving.

@SBK
Me too.
"Sorry, I didn't catch your name"
"I'm terrible with names"

@Grumpy Dad? Is that you? Listen, the program was marketed as a show about nothing. That description has stood the rest of time. (Read: it is absolutely not for everyone.) As a teenager in a one tv household, I had to enjoy it when I could because my parents hated it. So I happily support your demand for exclusion from categorization that my original comment imposed on the entire population of the puzzle community at large. I can only assume that you read "Hello, new man" as the revealer and enjoyed how it wrapped up the theme void of imagery of Jerry Seinfeld with a white turtleneck, denim button-down, and limited acting skills fighting to hold a scowl when he delivered that iconic line. Meanwhile, I have to admit that I wrote that just waiting for someone to come along with such a disclaimer. "Cancelled over 25 years ago" doesn't accurately describe the circumstances of its wrap and fails capture its impact on pop culture - whether that impact produces a snicker or an eyeroll as it emerges "in the language."

@Francis The correction was fully embraced for both the integrity of the reference and the laugh that I got out of it. I did fail to congratulate you on the win you shared! I have never participated in such a contest, but I can confidently assert that my competitors wouldn't stand a chance. üòÜ

@Mark

Right? It's the same in Polish. My dad had once worked as a masons's assistant and he always corrected me when I made the cement/beton (cement/concrete) mistake. Strange to see it at the NYT.

Also, the clue for the singular PALM implies plural... (Sources...)

This has to be one of the worst edited NYT puzzles in quite some time.

@Mark
A trowel is used to put cement on the bricks when laying them. Same for stones and cinder blocks. The clue is fine.

@Andrzej
See my reply to that Mark fellow.

@Bob

Not cement, which is the powder that comes in sacks - concrete, which is what you get when you mix cement, water, sand and possibly gravel.

@Bob
I believe you are referring to mortar

@Tradcarp
I've heard cement and mortar casually used interchangeably when laying bricks, possibly wrongly.

@Andrzej
Bricklayers, and I know a few - both sides of my family and half my in-laws, call it cement when they work with it. Actually, they call it mud more than they call it cement, but almost never do they call it mortar. Colloquial usage by those who work with it every day trumps anything else, so no: I meant cement. I'm not just making stuff up.

@Tradcarp
If I wanted to write mortar, I would write mortar. See my last response to Andrzej for an explanation. Having known and grown up with scores of members of the BAC local 1 and having put down some mud, or cement, I can assure you I have not some little domain knowledge.

@Jane Wheelaghan
This is true to an extent. Not sure about your side of the ocean, but "mud" is actually the most common term for it I hear from actual masons with cement coming in second and mortar a far distant third.

@Bob
Mud definitely not used! I've known bricklayers.

@Jane Wheelaghan
Mud definitely used!  I was a bricklayer.

@Jacqui J for a girl ‚û°Ô∏è womanhood theme, we could go with BAT MITZVAH, QUINCEA√ëERA and SWEET SIXTEEN. Are the any others I‚Äôm not thinking of from other cultures? The revealer could be the TV show NEW GIRL starring Zooey Deschanel üòâ

@Jacqui J
The quincea√±era and the sweet sixteen - I've not heard of them being celebrated in the UK. A long time ago, the 21st birthday used to be a huge celebration (it was the voting age then). 

One focus was "the key of the door". When young men and women mostly stayed at home until they got married, they were considered an adult at 21 and not until then did they get a key to the door of the house. Cards were sent with keys on them. Cakes had keys on them. This was when only a tiny proportion went to further education/university.

When the voting age was reduced to 18, the whole 21 celebration sort of faded away. There are 18th parties but without so much of the 'you're an adult now' feeling. The legal drinking age is 18, but a great many young people drink from age 15/16 so that's not really such a big deal!
@Jacqui J Sweet sixteen? Is that still a thing? It was never practiced by everyone, in any case.
@Jacqui J I just remembered that Spain does the Camino de Santiago as a rite of passage, but that isn‚Äôt female specific. Any other rites of passage? I love learning about this kind of stuff!
@Jane Wheelaghan what a wonderful rite of passage that used to be. 21 is the drinking age here, so there are definitely big celebrations around that birthday.

userLocation: ICE in Italia? Basta, ruffiani! Fuori!
commentBody:
@Jacqui J
Big one when I was growing up was getting your driver's licence. The minimum age was 16 and plenty of my classmates trooped off to the DMV the morning after their birthday to get their learner's licence. I had already been shipped off to college and didn't manage to get my licence until I was (oh, humiliation!) 18. Still ashamed.

@Jane Wheelaghan

Probably because so much of the USA requires the automobile just to cover daily activities.  When I was a lad in NYC, the state drinking age was 18 and we all used public transit.

Drunken driving deaths of teenagers became an issue and Mothers Against Drunk Driving (MADD) became a potent political force.  Now it's 21  everywhere, I believe, since states yield to federal government control of much funding.  
(Insurance co's lobbied for the higher age too.)

Now they have the right to vote and to join the military at 18 but they can't have a beer.

@Andrzej

It might be cool that have a screen that says "You are so far from getting this you might as well just give up now."

I strikes me that in my vanilla Protestant upbringing I never really had a formal rite of passage.  I guess my extended family held that going out of football was a kind of rite of passage.  But I was really bad at football, other than being slightly bigger than many of the kids on my side of town.  I didn't like getting hurt.

Moreover, I can't think of a point in time when I suddenly realized I wasn't a kid anymore, not by anyone's definition.  I think they sneaked up and threw adulthood all over me without my permission.

Fortunately, my adulthood is giving way to second childhood.  I think I'm about back to the 11th grade.

@Grumpy

That's the siIIiest adage of them all though - if it applies at any time and place, then maybe at a funeral, but not every one, either!

@Wendy P

Sure, but I didn't celebrate any of those things, and there was no aura of celebration about them in the family. It was just stuff that happened. I didn't find any of it symbolic. My wife and I got married at city hall with just the two mandatory witnesses present - that's how much I don't care about rites. Please don't take it away from me üôÉ
@Francis High school graduation is the primary, common rite of passage in the US, regardless of religious beliefs.

@Andrzej

I concede.‚ò∫Ô∏è

@Wendy P

ü´∂
@Andrzej please don‚Äôt tell me there are no Jews left in Poland. Lots of Americans know the rite of passage.

@Kris H

There are very few Jews in Poland - millions died in WW2, and many of those who survived were forced to emigrate in 1968 during a nationalist, antisemitic campaign of the then dictator, Gomu≈Çka. Some came back after 1989, and my ex boss from the law firm I used to work with is one of the pillars of Warsaw's 700-strong Jewish community (that's 700 people out of 2 000 000 Warsaw inhabitants, compared to hundreds of thousands out of 1,2 million before WW2). Jewish rites are not something I encounter in my Polish life - I have learned about them from books, films, and TV.

commentBody:
@Kris H
He didn't quite say that but it is painfully close to being true. A second cousin on my mother's side has tracked me down and is interrogating me about our joint family history. (So relentless is she, that she has sent her spit to /three/ genetic testing companies. I intend to keep my spit to myself.) It is mighty sad to keep responding to her queries based on birth, marriage and census documents with: "Dead. Murdered by the Nazis. Last seen alive in 1942. Thrown off a train while escaping..." 
And don't imagine that this is in any way an unusual family story for a Polish-Jewish family. Absolutely run of the mill.
There are millions of Jews thronging Poland, but they are all ghosts.

commentBody:

I join those who think you might enjoy "Seinfeld." First, I was not a fan which (let's  be frank) bodes well for you. As for RUMSPRINGA--similarly, a clue about the Amish is much easier for many Americans (note, I said "many," not "all").  It's where Amish teens get to be regular people for a while to see if they want to live their adult lives as Amish.

commentBody:
@Jane Wheelaghan

My son is a resident doc,
and I asked him about this when
hubby was in the hospital in December
with a heart scare.

Francis is correct- EKG is the German initialism,
but it is oddly more commonly used in the US
than ECG.
(At least at our hospital.)

So we call electrocardiograms EKGs.

Go figure.

@CCNY

I've read that doctors prefer EKG in order to avoid auditory confusion between ECG and EEG.

@Steve L

Hmm..I guess that makes sense.

Though it is somewhat terrifying to think
how many *slight* pronunciation differences
there must be in the medical field.

And recalling my husband's 
(incredible) cardiologist's profound accent...
along with his virtually
undecipherable handwriting...

Ooh. 
I get the jibblies.

@CCNY
That's interesting, thank you all.

commentBody: @The X-Phile The photo's ident information on the agency website is given as 1955. See here: https://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/javelin-thower-practising-the-correct-angle-news-photo/3368508

Yes, but you spread concrete with a float, not a TROWEL. I assumed the clue referred to bricklaying, in which case cement (with no aggregate added) was just fine.

@Grant It‚Äôs perfectly common to use a trowel in concrete work and unwise to use cement without sand for anything structural. A bricklayer uses mortar, which is also distinct from concrete and cement. I agree with Blake on this one.

@Barry Ancona

'I may be the only solver who knew all three themers 
but did not know the ["Seinfeld" catchphrase].'

Not true. I knew all three themers but did not know the Seinfeld catchphrase.

I think the VISION QUEST is fascinating. I remember a scene in a TV show called "Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman." A young man is on a vision quest. He isn't supposed to move or eat or drink, etc. He is sitting cross-legged in a field and a herd of stampeding buffalo rushes past all around him! He doesn't flinch.

By the way, I've read that buffalo are actually very fast runners.

Also by the way, for those who don't know, the Amish rite of passage allows teens to run off and go to the city and carouse and do what they want, I believe, and then they come back to the community and follow the strict Amish ways, I guess. Or not.

Margaret Mead describes a similar situation in her famous book "Coming of Age in Samoa." The teens have a special "bunk" they live in and live it up, and then later adopt the routine ways of their group.

LISA is a stage name for Lalisa Manobal, nee Pranpriya Manobal.  She changed her first name on the advice of a fortune teller.

@Kris
Interesting. Just shows how much I don't know about K-pop. (I did watch "Demon Hunters.")
@Grant she is also known for her character in White Lotus season 3

@Endall

This is a board where we tell others about our solving experiences. Sometimes that involves not knowing things. Your highbrow condescension is not welcome. First, there is nothing wrong with pop culture. Second, all people lead complex lives and they learn things along the way. The elitism of those who expect everybody *should* know some things was a good look in a Victorian salon, maybe, but it no longer is.

@Endall
Just remember that Shakespeare was pop culture once. I'm not saying Blackpink is timeless, but maybe "Seinfeld" comes close. Italian Renaissance painters always trip me up.

@Endall

I think I understand where you are coming from, but for me, the issue isn‚Äôt that people don‚Äôt ‚Äúknow‚Äù things, but rather that they know a ton about things like pop culture and sports to the exclusion of other knowledge. I found some of this puzzle somewhat difficult because I‚Äôm not American, have never watched a lot of tv or movies, don‚Äôt listen to pop music, and don‚Äôt follow sports (US or otherwise).

A co-worker of mine easily solved those clues, because he is a walking encyclopedia of pop culture are US sports knowledge, whereas he couldn‚Äôt name the primary belligerents in WW2. He can‚Äôt point to Spain on an unmarked map. He knows nothing about music recorded prior to about 1998, let alone basic music theory. Has never read a single book, let alone anything that could be classified as literature or a ‚Äúclassic‚Äù. Can recite the menu of every fast food chain in the US or Canada, drinks a six pack of soda per day, but otherwise knows nothing about food or cuisine.

In the context of playing a game like a crossword puzzle, all knowledge has equal weight. But for societies, having an incredible depth of knowledge about pop culture at the expense of other types of knowledge is problematic.

@Endall

I hope no one here gave you the impression you or your comments aren't welcome.

I tend to agree with you about wishing more people knew more about non-pop culture.  I am particularly appalled at how little most people know about the way our government is supposed to work.  I think the schools stopped teaching civics some year ago, and I think we are suffering greatly because of it.

But I can also see it in the utterly horrifying number of flat earth you tubes.  It literally makes my stomach role.

You are well-spoken and polite even though you are being critical.  Not a thing wrong with that.

@Max Power and Endall

People can both know a ton of things about pop culture‚Äîand‚Äîabout other kinds of knowledge. 

Perhaps I just know exceptionally balanced people, but I don't think it's an either/or deal for the majority of us. Most of us have interests in the pop culture we find enjoyable, along with a variety of other areas of knowledge.

For example, Seinfeld is an area of pop culture knowledge for me and I got the revealer immediately‚Äîthough I have never heard of LISA the rapper. 

I also knew (not pop culture) DELHI immediately and OSAGE. I knew HEISTS from the movies but would have preferred it was clued as part of my favorite TV show. And even though I can probably still quote most of the Princess Bride, I can also point to Spain on an unmarked map and tell you who the WWII baddies were. 

While there may be extremes, most of us are just a wonderful mixture of time, place, experience, aptitude, interest, and opportunity. I wouldn't want it any other way. People are wonderful!

Anyhow, just trying to avoid these kind of generalities. I don't think they help anyone.

@HeathieJ

I agree with that completely, and that was even something I tried to convey in my post. I have no issue with pop culture, and I am no kind of elitist. I knew the Seinfeld reference as well, can also quote most of the Princess Bride, and most of the first 10 seasons of the Simpsons to boot (I‚Äôm a gen Xer). I wouldn‚Äôt be able to function very well socially if I didn‚Äôt have some baseline knowledge of pop culture. For better or worse, it binds us like shared experiences and shapes our collective consciousness.

My specific argument was that having a deep knowledge of pop culture and nothing else is an issue. I would even argue that if a person was utterly ignorant of other forms of knowledge (for instance, history or science), they would be better to have no knowledge of pop culture at all, as they would lack the framework to parse that flood of unfiltered content. Pop culture doesn‚Äôt demand any great degree of critical thinking from us, only that we consume it - which is absolutely fine when it‚Äôs consumed as a diversion. Pop culture is to society as junk food is to nutrition.

The exception I took with the OP‚Äôs post was his implication that crosswords should be above pop culture knowledge. But I do agree with his view that the glorification of pop culture is detrimental to our society. Our memories and time both being in limited supply means that for most of us, the more of that kind of knowledge we retain, the less of everything else there will be.

@Max Power

Well, GIVEMEFIVE, fellow GEN Xer!

Apologies if I wasn't clear on what you were trying to convey. Your first message read (to me) like you consider this glorification of pop culture (and people like your co-worker) to currently be a huge problem in our societies, and I personally don't see that being the case.

Honestly, I don't always know what pop culture is really supposed to include. I mean, as Grant mentioned above, Shakespeare was once pop culture. Probably a lot of the arts were or are, but there's a depth of understanding of humanity and beauty to be learned through them that is as worthy as the other types of knowledge. We see it not as trivial now, who knows what will stand the test of time and importance over the next generations. 

Anyhow, I appreciate your clarification. We're probably not all that far apart on this. ‚ò∫Ô∏è
@H.E. -- I ought to try that sometime.

Unsurprisingly, PALM has been a topic of discussion here in the comments since yesterday. First thread: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/4dned4?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

@MSFTGirl

At first, I was confused by what you were offering, but I figured out that you were offering a tip that can be generalized as:

If you want to be a good solver, always consider that a word may have various definitions.  Some of those variances relate to the way it is used in a sentence (part of speech).

Other times, it's a matter of words having widely diverse meanings, because one modern word comes from a variety of ancestors.  "Fair" comes to mind:  a carnival, good (weather), so-so (a grade), light-complexioned, just (fair and square), etc.

A good solver considers that a clue does not always match up with the first thing that comes to mind.
